oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Milk Yield, Somatic Cell Counts and Risk of Removal from the Herd for Dairy Cows after Covered Teat Canal Injury
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Quereng√§sser, K.
Geishauser, T.
Nitschke, M.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: milk yield
somatic cell count
risk of removal
covered teat injury
endoscopy
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The objective of the study reported here was to evaluate milk yield, somatic cell count (SCC), and risk of removal of cows from the herd after covered teat injury. In covered teat injuries the teat skin is relatively undamaged. Eighty-one patients were used for this study. Teat injuries were diagnosed and treated using endoscopy (Medl et al. 1994). After treatment teats were rested for 3 x 3 days (Geishauser et al. 1998). Each patient was matched to three herdmates by breed, age and calving date. Data on milk yield and SCC were available from DHI records.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: American Association of Bovine Practitioners Conference Proceedings; 1999; 182-183
